reviewText: Monarch of the Glen is one of the more charming television series to come out of the UK. It follows the troubles and tribulations of the MacDonald clan, who's young laird, Archie, has been put in charge of leading the family estate out of debt. It's not as easy as it sounds, as Archie not only tries to balance the wishes of his mother and father with the agendas of the the estate's workers, but most also choose between his life in London with restaurateur business partner Justine, or live in Glenbogle with the mysterious Katrina.The locations are beautiful, the writing top-notch, and the performances are a delight to watch. Alastair Mackenzie is the center of the ensemble as Laird Archie, but is nicely rounded out by the other performers, the most outstanding in this first series being Dawn Steele as the feisty cook, Lexie, and Hamish Clark as the bumbling handyman, Duncan.The 2-Disc DVD presentation of the first series is just as well-produced as the program the discs hold. The picture is spot-less with little noticeable PAL-to-NTSC conversion artifacts, and is presented in 16x9 enhanced wide-screen looking far better than the show has aired on BBC America or PBS. The 2.0 sound mix is clear and dialogue is always intelligible. There is little in the way of extras, simply cast biographies and a six minute excerpt from BBC series "Holiday" about the locations that Monarch uses and brief interviews with the actors.If you're looking for an American program to compare this to the closest that I could point you to is "Ed," but even then, Ed is never as good-natured and beautifully produced as this fine Scottish gem. Most definitely recommended.
summary: Winning television-program on a finely produced DVD...
Title: N/A

reviewText: This series has eight episodes on the DVD.  It is a strong ensemble drama/comedy.What I like:  The scenery of Scotland.  The premise of a 21st Century Scottish Laird having real 21st Century concerns.  The estate is not only home but, must also be an ongoing productive concern.  We can all identify trying to get credit extension from a bank.  You can only be amused thinking of say, Mary Queen of Scots, having to go through this.  The actors Hamish Clark as Duncan and Alexander Morton as Golly are compelling characters.Other matters:  I know this is an ensemble series.  However, even ensembles need a strong anchor character.  For example, Star Trek=Captain Kirk.  Alisdair Mackenzie sometimes seems overwhelmed by the other characters.  Whether it's, Katrina, Lexie, Duncan, or Hector, his screen oxygen seems to be taken away from him when the others appear.  His love interest/business partner, Justine, is not likable.  The writers have made his end choices obvious.  Having Justine as less of a BOW would have made things better for an already excellent series.I would recommend the series to those who like ensembles of any genre.  Despite my concerns the first season has got me to watching the 2nd season.

reviewText: This is a politically correct Scottish soap opera.  Yes, the scenery is great, and Susan Hampshire and Richard Briers are excellent actors.  But the script is awful.  It's the likes of what one finds on CBS at 10:00 a.m. on weekdays.  Of course, the soaps have millions of fans, and there can be no better reason for this series to have lasted as long as it did.  If sulking, sobbing, quarreling, and sexual innuendo is your thing, enjoy.  In fact, this is neither comedy nor effective drama.

reviewText: As an American watching this series, my whole family has been captivated by it.  This season is especially good.  Set in Scotland, in the Highlands, it centers upon the return of Archie to his home and the difficulties he encounters trying to turn the estate into a profitable venture.  I have to admit, we use the subtitles as not being familiar with this style of English we find them helpful.  This series provides hours of engrossing entertainment.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I had never heard of Monarch of the Glen until a friend recently loaned me his DVD set and am I glad he did. This is a wonderful series. The scenery alone will keep you spellbound long enough to get to know all the characters. The show is so well written that all the players are real, complex people.Archie MacDonald has just opened a restaurent in London with his girlfriend when he is called back to his home in the Scottish highlands. His parents tell him that he is now Laird of his ancestral home of Glenbogle and it's in trouble, 300,000 pounds in debt. Archie must decide whether to just sell the land that has been in his family for 400 years or stay and try to save it any way he can.Archie's conflict of wanting to save the estate but also feeling like he never belonged there in the first place drive this first series. Along the way family secrets and tragedies are revealed that explain some of Archie's feelings and especially the behavior of his irrascible and slightly loony father Hector. The series is essentially a drama with humor and romance thrown into the mix. It is so well done that everything blends together perfectly. Monarch of the Glen is a confluence of a good story, great writing, acting, and beautiful scenery.
summary: Will charm you from the first episode
Title: N/A

reviewText: As a fan of British mystery and drama I'm always on the lookout for a new series, at least new to me that I can enjoy. Fortunately I've been privileged to discover a number of series that fall into that category, most recently Monarch of the Glen. This one definitely moves the action to a location different from any series watched to this date.This one is set in the highlands of Scotland amidst beautiful lakes, mountains and valleys; that alone would make the series notable in my opinion. The story is filled with interesting characters whose actions and motivations all contribute to an absorbing storyline. The hero of the story is a young second son who is compelled by circumstances to return to the familie's castle in the highlands of Scotland. Further surprises await him when he makes some life changing discoveries concerning his status in the family.The video and audio are good, the acting and scenery are good and the characters are interesting enough to generate some concern about what happens to them. That combination makes for a sure winner and when you combine that with six series of 8 to 11 episodes each then you have a winning combination offering many evenings of entertainment.We've watched a number of the episodes from series 1 and must admit we're hooked and looking forward to the next episode.Highly recommended

reviewText: If you're looking for a Downton Abbey substitute, you'll find many, but not all, of its best qualities in Monarch of the Glen. Its setting is contemporary Scotland, not early 1900s England, and its humor is broader than Downton's, but it has the same upstairs/downstairs dynamic and its Scottish Highlands scenery is stunning. Since it's the beginning of this century rather than the last, many members of the aristocracy are no longer wealthy, and the ongoing struggle to save Glenbogle, the grand but increasingly decrepit McDonald family estate, is one of the main drivers of the plot. Archie McDonald, just made Laird (Lord) after his father steps down, is forced to give up his life in London and the restaurant he was planning to run with Justine, his sophisticated girlfriend, so he can help his cheerful but fiscally clueless parents figure out how to keep Glenbogle solvent. The very urban Justine tries to make a go of living in the country, but Archie has also caught the eye of several local women, including Lexie, the cheeky family cook, and Katrina, a village school teacher bent on political reform. Julian Fellows, the creator of Downton Abbey,  plays the earl next door, a friend and rival of Archie's father. It's a fun first season with a different glimpse of the British Isle.
summary: Downton Abbey creator plays the earl next door

reviewText: This is an utterly charming romantic sitcom set in a beautiful old castle in the Scottish highlands.  The acting is superb, the characters are mostly extremely likeable (with a couple of jerks thrown in just to make it interesting) and the accents are not impossible to understand as is unfortunately true with some British tv. This show carries on the standards of such wonderful shows as "Good Neighbors" and "To the Manor Born."  Actually it's pretty much the same plot as "Manor" except this time it's told from the Laird's point of view. Pretty darn wonderful.
summary: As good a British sitcom as you're likely to see

They're all wonderful.The location is beautiful, too.  It's another character all together.

reviewText: Take a bad soap opera.  Staff it with the worst actors you can find.  Throw in some absurd & silly plots.  Then insist the actors--all in the name of "genuine accents" of course--speak as if they all have mush (excuse me, oatmeal) in their mouths.  Mix it all together, and you have some idea of the farce that is pedaled here.  I challenge anyone but the most dedicated Scot (all 1000 of them) to understand more than 50% of the spoken dialogue.If you want to see some nice scenery, well, OK I get it.  Clouds served up on demand, but it's still a nice setting.  But the acting & the plots are excruciatingly and mind-numbingly opaque and silly.  Read a book, put a puzzle together, spend time with your loved ones, but avoid this joke.
summary: Truly Awful in every possible way

reviewText: I've been asked through the years if I've seen "Monarch of the Glen," but alas, it wasn't carried by any of the PBS stations in my area.  Finally broke over and got the DVD and I'm very glad I did.Let's just start with the view.  Scotland's one of the most beautiful places I have ever been and the producers of this series took full advantage of the country's scenic endowments.  The music is not just carefully placed bagpipes, it's a mix of traditional and contemporary instrumentals that enhances the scenes.  And of course the acting.  The well-chosen ensemble cast plays off of each other beautifully.So, what happens?  In the beginning, Archie MacDonald is a London restauranteur who is concerned about getting the business running right.  He gets a call from Glenbogle, Scotland that his father Hector has been hurt in the Loch and rushes home to help.  He arrives to find that his father is fine and feisty as ever, but the estate's in trouble and they've made him laird.  He's got to stay and help despite the havoc this wreaks on his personal and business relationship.  As Archie learns to work with the people and the land, he's growing fond of the place and it's more and more doubtful that he will return to his previous life.Rebecca Kyle, September 2009
